div.p: BANDINI, Angelo Maria, a learned Italian, was born at Florence on the 25th of September 1726. Having been left an orphan in his infaney, he was supported by his uncle, Joseph Bandini, a lawyer of some note. He received his education among the Jesuits, and discovered an early passion for the study of antiquities. A desire which he also manifested to distinguish himself as a poet was fortunately checked by the ill suecess of his first attempt; and, from that period, he devoted himself principally to literary history and archaeological seience. The celebrated Dr Lami, with whom he had the good fortune to contract a friendship, assisted him with his counsels, and encouraged him to persevere in that path to whieh his genius seems to have directed him.

In the year 1747 Bandini undertook a journey to Vienna, in company with the bishop of Volterra, to whom he acted in the capacity of secretary. He was introduced to the emperor, and took the opportunity of dedieating to that monareh his Specimen Litteraturce Florentinae, which was then printing at Florence. In the following year he , returned by the way of Veniee, Padua, Ferrara, and Bologna, and united himself in friendship with the learned men in all these cities. Having resided some time at Florence, he repaired to Rome, and entered into orders, passing the whole of his time in the library of the Vatican, and in those of the Cardinals Passionei and Corsini. At that time the famous obelisk of Augustus was disinterred from the ruins of the Campus Martius. Bandini, by the order of Benedict XIV., undertook to describe and explain this eurious monument; but finding that the air of Rome was injurious to his health, he returned to Florence. In 1750 lie was selected by Alexander Marueelli to take charge of the valuable library whieh his unele. the Abbé Franeis Marueelli had left, and whieh, according to the will of the founder, was to be open to the public. But he had scarcely entered upon the duties of this eharge when the proprietor died, after bequeathing all his effects to the library, and appointing the Abbé Bandini perpetual librarian and his testamentary exeeutor. It required two years to liquidate the succession and to form the complete catalogue of this vast library, whieh was at length opened to the publie in the year 1752. In 1756 he was preferred by the emperor to a prebend at Florence, and appointed principal'librarian to the Laurentian library. During forty-four years he continued to discharge the duties of this situation, and died in 1800, generally esteemed and regretted. On his death-bed he founded a public sehool, and bequeathed the remainder of his fortune to other eharitable purposes.

The first work by whieh Bandini beeame known as a man of letters was his Dissertatio de Veterum Saltationibus, which he wrote at the age of twenty-two, and which was inserted by his learned friend Lami in the fifth volume of the works of Meursius, published in 1745. The most remarkable of his other works are, 1. Specimen Lit-teraturae Florentinae Seeuli XV. &e. 2 vols. 8vo. 2. De Obelisco Augusti Caesaris, e Campi Martii Ruderibus nuper eruto. 1750, fol. 3. Collectio .Veterum aliquot Monumentorum ad Historiam, praeeipue Litterariam, pertinentium. 1752, 8vo. 4. Elogio dell’ ab. Francisco Marueelli Fondatore della Publica Libreria Marueelliana. 1754, 4to. 5. Vita e Lettere di Amerigo Vespueei. 1745, 4to. 6. De Vita et Seriptis Joan. Bapt. Donii Patrieii Florentini libri V. Adnotationibus illustrati; aeeedit ejusdem Donii litterarium Commereium, nune primum in lucem editum. 1755, fol. 7. Vita di Filippo Strozzi. 1756, 4to. 8. Vita del Cardin. Niceolo da Prato. Eod. an. 4to. 9. From 1763 to 1766 he employed himself in publishing successively the works of some of the minor Greek poets, whieh he enriehed with notes and various readings. These were Callimachus; the two poems of Nieander on Poisons and Antidotes; the Phenomena of Aratus; the Poems of Musaeus; those of Coluthus on the Rape of Helen, and Tryphiodorus on the taking of Troy; Theognis, Phoeylides, and the golden verses of Pythagoras. The Greek text of these poems was earefully collated with the best manuscripts; and there were added translations in Italian verse by Ant. Mar. Salvini. 10.
